awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  NanoOptics - Highly efficient scintillator photonic devices for national security, medical imaging and high energy particle detection applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Inorganic scintillators are widely used in modern medical imaging modalities (as converter for the x-rays and ã-radiation that are used to obtain information about the interior of the body, like x-ray, CT and PET scan), national security, airport security, and high energy particle detector. One key problem in the development of the next generation scintillator systems is the enhancement of the timing, positioning and energy resolution of the detectors. Most of the high-density scintillators have a high refractive index; only less than 10% of the light from the scintillator can enter into the photo detector. This seriously impacts the detection system's efficiency and detection sensitivity. This team has developed a novel class of nano-scale photonic structures that function as efficient light extraction devices for scintillator materials and devices. This is an emerging field and the proposed research has made the overall efficiency of these scintillator materials increase significantly.

The unique properties of the nature-inspired nano-scale photonic structures allow one to engineer the output light beam shape, so that the angular behavior of the light can be controlled. This makes smaller pixel, higher imaging resolution possible for the next generation of integrated scintillator devices, with a variety of application possible in market areas including national security and medical imaging. This I-Corps team will work together to seek out market opportunities for commercialization of the innovation, discovering new and previously uncharted applications based on conversations with many potential customers throughout the United States.

por.por_cntn:
The demand for higher efficient medical imaging scintillator devices is expected to boom. There is also a huge incentive to provide highly sensitive radiation detection devices for both national security and medical imaging purposes. Scintillator devices are basic building blocks for these key applications. Next generation scintillator materials and devices with higher efficiency and directional beam control will be critical to achieve these goals. The objective of the proposed project is to commercialize novel nanostructured thin-film devices projected to have a transformative impact on a wide range of technologies ranging from medical imaging, high energy particle detection and homeland security applications. Here, we propose commercializing aspects of this project, we believe that doing so will allow us expand and continue this project, making it an even more integral part of this innovation technology at all levels in the future.
Intellectual merit:   The optical performance of scintillator detectors, which is one of the most important components in the medical imaging instrument with key functionality to convert x-ray or γ-ray to visible light, has become a bottleneck for achieving low dose from medical imaging. Our innovative technology has exploited the basic imaging characteristics of the scintillator materials with integrated nanophotonic structures to determine the feasibility of ultimate goal for next generation radiation detection scintillator devices for lower dose, higher timing/energy/position resolution medical imaging and homeland security applications. Our innovation provides an exciting route to achieve this goal, to fabricate, inexpensively, nanophotonic films in sufficient density and quantity for industrial scale applications, where large area deposition is often called for. 
Broader impacts: The greater Detroit metropolitan area has encountered unprecedented challenges and difficulties for the last few years. Since the great recession beginning at late 2008, two of the three biggest American automobile manufacturers (GM, Ford and Chrysler) have gone through bankruptcy and are only slowly coming back recently. City of Detroit, once one of the biggest cities in the United States, has declared bankruptcy protection last year.  To revive the local economy and the Detroit metropolitan area, the State of Michigan has implemented a strategic economic diversification program. A few emerging and innovative economic growth areas, including smart and intelligent vehicle system, renewable and clean energy, life sciences, and nanotechnology have been proposed, in addition to the traditional automotive industry. New technology and high quality engineers are the most deciding factors to achieve this goal. The proposed project in medical imaging and homeland security field will help UM provide the fundamental infrastructure to make realizing these multidisciplinary initiatives possible. Much of the proposed project involves a multidisciplinary collaboration between the related departments, colleges and across the local area with other colleges and industries. This proposed project will critically enable us to initiate active medical imaging and homeland security commercialization programs across the highly impacted Southeastern Michigan area and make critical contributions to achieve our goal to revive the dynamics of the great Detroit metropolitan area again in the coming decade.

During the project, we have interviewed more than 100 personals related to the scintillator detector field, we have learned in the following:
1. The potential customers and applications in medical imaging field.
2. The potential customers and applications in security field.
3. The scintillator detector applied to the high energy particle detection field.
4. What are potential customers and what are really their needs and what our technology can provide.


The whole team, including both PI and EL have truly learned from the customer discovery process, which we appreciate the I-corps prgram gave us this great opportunity from lab to potentail customer and market discovery.
